headline.main: Answers About Health in New York, Part 3

docs.abstract: Answers from James R. Knickman, the president and chief executive of the New York State Health Foundation, who took questions from readers this week about health coverage and a range of related issues.
docs.lead_paragraph: Following is a third and final set of answers from James R. Knickman, the president and chief executive of the New York State Health Foundation, who took questions from readers during the past week on a range of issues from universal health care and Medicaid to the prevalence in New York of problems like obesity, diabetes, smoking and substance abuse.
docs.snippet: Answers from James R. Knickman, the president and chief executive of the New York State Health Foundation, who took questions from readers this week about health coverage and a range of related issues.

headline.print_headline: Medical Specialties and Our Health Care System
headline.main: Medical Specialties and Our Health Care System
Fat City? 10 Million Pounds Gained in 2 Years

docs.abstract: New York City's rates of obesity and new diabetes diagnoses both increased by 17 percent during a two-year study period, well above comparable rates nationwide.
docs.lead_paragraph: About 173,500 adult New Yorkers became obese and more than 73,000 received new diagnoses of diabetes from 2002 to 2004, according to a new study by the New York City Department of Health and Mental Hygiene. Put another way, "the citywide weight gain totaled more than 10 million pounds in just two years," the city noted in a news release summarizing the study, which is being published in the April issue of Preventing Chronic Disease, a medical journal published by the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention.
docs.snippet: New York City's rates of obesity and new diabetes diagnoses both increased by 17 percent during a two-year study period, well above comparable rates nationwide.

headline.main: Answers About Health in New York, Part 2

docs.abstract: Answers from James R. Knickman, the president and chief executive of the New York State Health Foundation, who is taking questions from readers this week about health coverage and related issues.
docs.lead_paragraph: Following is a second set of answers from James R. Knickman, the president and chief executive of the New York State Health Foundation, who is taking questions from readers through March 29 on a range of issues from universal health care and Medicaid to the prevalence in New York of problems like obesity, diabetes, smoking and substance abuse. Readers are invited to submit additional questions using the comment form below.

headline.seo: PatientsLikeMe - Medicine - Doctors - Computers and the Internet

docs.lead_paragraph: PatientsLikeMe, an Internet start-up, creates information-rich communities for the chronically ill. Is it the next step forward in medical science — or just a MySpace for the afflicted?
docs.snippet: PatientsLikeMe, an Internet start-up, creates information-rich communities for the chronically ill. Is it the next step forward in medical science — or just a MySpace for the afflicted?
